text: Pyro Source + Volume Rasterize Attributes + ecstasy.
This node is basically a love child of the

. 
It creates points for sourcing pyro and smoke simulations and samples point attributes into VDBs (2nd Output).
It also contains the most common operations and functions for pyro source creations.
Handy stuff like: attribute noises, trail creation, aging, mask by bounds (for grid type sources), clipping plane and a few more.
It is NOT intented to replace the

!
    This node is only recommended for simple tasks. For advanced cases, it’s probably better to build your own node tree,
    but for simple tasks it can be effective and can speed up your workflow. Just be wise!
You can jump into the node. There’s an editable subnet for your custom operations.

, the geometry must correspond to a surface; in the latter case,
    the surface must also have a resolvable interior.
1st Output: Particles with the assigned attributes.
Controls which points are exported by the node.
Points of the incoming geometry are used unchanged.
Points are scattered on the surface of the input geometry.
Points are scattered in the interior of the input geometry.

parameter, but feel free to unlink it and set an arbitrary value if needed.

Shows the volume result, but only as visualization. This means the first output of the node won’t change.
    Note that only
is set to be visible, every other volume will be invisible in the viewport.

, yielding a

Determines the courseness of the noise.
Turn this on to shape the output of the noise with a ramp.

This ramp lets you control the output of the noise function. The horizontal axis represents the range (minimum on the left, maximum on the right). The vertical axis represents the number to output when the noise function generates that point within the range.

Enables trail creation. Useful for moving points to prevent steppy source.

Determines how many points are there in a trail.
    The more points the trails have the smoother the volume rasterization will be.

option. This is mainly for situations when you have grid type sources.

This tab is only visible if

When enabled, points will be relaxed, pushed away from each other, to avoid clumping.  This is done gradually, to avoid chaotic behavior and to allow
    control over how much relaxation takes place.  More relaxation iterations results in points that are more separated from each other.  A distribution
    of points in which they are well separated is often called

The amount of jitter to apply to the positional values of the points.  
    Jitter causes random changes to the positions of the points.
Set this value to 0 if no jitter whatsoever is desired.

attribute.

    to be as highres as

and the other fields, because it won’t cause significant changes

volume. 2 will double the voxel size, so result in half the resolution,
    and one eighth the total voxels.
